question: What role did Thomas Jefferson play in the drafting of the Declaration of Independence, and how was his contribution recognized by his contemporaries?

He was chosen by Benjamin Franklin and John Adams to write the document, and he did most of the work, drafting it in his lodgings at 7th and Market Street. His contribution was recognized by his contemporaries as the document became the most famous document not only in American history but also in the history of the entire world. The Declaration of Independence explained why the colonies were breaking away from Great Britain, and it listed each of the bad things that King George III had done and the rights he had taken away. Jefferson's contribution was recognized as an expression of the American mind and a persuasive argument for the American colonies to gain independence.

Initially, General Braddock refused Washington\'s advice to dispense with wagons, insisting on pulling all his accustomed equipment through the unblazed wilderness, which caused the force to become badly dispersed over almost 20 miles. Eventually, Braddock relented and adopted Washington\'s suggestion to send an advance force of 1,200 men forward without wagons, leaving Washington behind. The British officers, except for Washington, were either wounded or killed. Colonial troops attempted to fight the French on their own terms in the woods but were mistakenly fired upon by their British allies. Despite the defeat being one of the worst in British colonial history, Washington emerged as a "bullet proof hero of the Monongahela."']

In late November 1758, the French, believing the British would not strike until spring, evacuated Fort Duquesne after destroying their cannon. Washington and his vanguard marched in on November 25, 1758, and raised the British flag on the ruins, renaming it Fort Pitt. This event concluded five years of conflict to secure the Forks of the Ohio, with peace established between the British and local Indian tribes. George Washington played a key role by leading his troops to occupy the fort and later viewing the transformation of the French fort into Fort Pitt on Christmas morning 1758. His leadership during this campaign and subsequent decision to resign and return to Mount Vernon in early 1759 marked the end of his military service in the war and the beginning of his life as a landowner and public figure.']
